<[silence:3400]>
Tiny machines. Big possibilities.

<[silence:2400]>
"Nanotechnology" comes from nano, meaning one-billionth—like a marble compared to Earth.<[silence:1200]>
It’s engineering at the scale of atoms and molecules.<[silence:2400]

Most people picture sci-fi robots in your bloodstream.<[silence:1200]>
The reality is quieter but more powerful.<[silence:1200]>
At this size, materials behave differently.<[silence:1200]>
Gold isn’t shiny—it’s red or purple.<[silence:1200]>
Carbon atoms, arranged just right, become 200 times stronger than steel (graphene).<[silence:2400]

A sunscreen uses nano-sized zinc oxide.<[silence:1200]>
Normally, it’d leave a white film.<[silence:1200]>
At nano scale, it turns invisible while blocking UV rays.<[silence:1200]>
Doctors use gold nanoparticles to target cancer cells—heat them with lasers, sparing healthy tissue.<[silence:2400]

Nature does this already.<[silence:1200]>
Geckos stick to walls with nano-sized hairs on their feet.<[silence:1200]>
Lotus leaves repel water because their surface is covered in tiny bumps.<[silence:1200]>
We’re learning to copy these tricks.<[silence:2400]

The challenge?<[silence:1200]>
Building at this scale is like assembling a watch with boxing gloves on.<[silence:1200]>
Tools like atomic force microscopes let us see and move single atoms.<[silence:1200]>
But mass production is still slow.<[silence:2400]

Self-assembly.<[silence:1200]>
Quantum dots.<[silence:1200]>
Molecular manufacturing.
